data.text: Everyone is different, but would suggest leather saddles are best, brook imperial took less than 300miles to break in and wasn't uncomfortable before, also have a spa Aire leather saddle which has thicker leather than than the brooks but didn't need any breaking in at all, perhaps l was lucky.
data.author: Jim Benbow

data.text: I bought a gel saddle a decent one end of last year. Worst saddle ever in terms of comfort and noise. So have just replaced it with a b17. Only been out for a 20 km and 35 km ride once with padding and once without. Already more comfortable than the gel. So I guess I'm suggesting try whatever you think you'd like for an hour or 2 first if possible. A synthetic one will probably never change a leather one will et more comfy with time. I did buy my b17 secondhand so it had already done a few kms but not many

data.author: Bill Santore

data.text: IMHO, 1/2 of being comfortable is having a saddle that isn't awful, the other 1/2 is knowing how to be comfortable on the saddle you have. Bicycles aren't couches or even comfy chairs - you have to learn how to be comfortable on them. So get a good saddle that fits you and most people agree isn't awful. Then put in a couple of hours a day on it (an indoor trainer over the winter is a great way to do this). It won't be long and you'll find you never think about your saddle again.
data.author: Randy Phinney

data.text: specially having the proper saddle height based on or coupled with Bike Fitting.
data.author: Nuj Simon

data.text: What I really like about the seat on my recumbent is I never have the problem I used to have on my diamond frame bike . Over time the fabulous Brooks saddle turned from comfort to a fence post. The saddle did not change , just my anatomy grew weary . So having changed the design of bike completely , I have now got something to ride wherever my arthritic body parts can go and when I arrive I may have sore legs from distance but no longer any of the aches and pains I and so many other diamond frame riders take in stride as normal. To be fair though on my touring bent I changed the seat from the sporty narrow model that came from the factory and a huge amount of people love and bought a wider full mesh seat that I sit in, not on. Comfort and speed is what I have now , whereas a diamond frame bike will only give me speed , till my body objects .

data.author: Menno Pieters

data.text: You need to go to a bike shop and get measured. There are three things that matter. Width, profile (flat or rounded), and cutout. The correct saddle in the wrong width will still suck. The width of your sit bones has absolutely nothing to do with the size of you as a person. The profile is determined by the shape of your sit bones, and cutout is determined by soft tissue. I hated all saddles till I got a Specialized Power. Again, none of these three things has very much to do with being male or female, skinny or not.
data.author: Andrew Maljaars

data.text: Sella Italia lady Gel Flow Terry, Bella Brooks B17 (NEEDS CONDITIONED)
data.author: Pendulumn JoAn Miner

data.text: Your backside, your riding position, your anatomical specifics, your saddle. No one can tell you what will be best for you. In my case a Brooks B17 was comfy from day 1. Others hate it forever. Same with any other saddle. You need to put your backside on the saddle on your bike to know. Sorry‚Ä¶it‚Äôs just the way it is.
data.author: Mike Samsen

data.text: it's ok..
data.author: Jo Lowe

data.text: Go to a good bike shop and get the width of your sit bones measured. Regardless which saddle you buy, if the spots your sit bones rest on are too narrow, you‚Äôre going to feel like you‚Äôre sitting on the head of an axe all day. If you don‚Äôt have a good shop nearby there are videos on YouTube about how to measure them with corrugated cardboard. Also get a bike fit. No saddle will be comfortable if there‚Äôs too much weight on your butt, or if your butt hits the saddle at the wrong angle.
data.author: Bill Bulek

data.text: There is a method of pre-conditioning a Brooks saddle that almost entirely eliminates any break in period that I have used with great success on all my Brooks saddles over a great many years. It involves treating the saddle with a product called Hydrophane. Message me if interested in the whole process. Brooks really are the best saddles!
data.author: Tony Mitchelhill

data.text: Consider SMP
data.author: Nuj Simon

data.text: The problem with ‚Äúno break in saddles‚Äù (aside from sella anat√≥mica) is they break down as you use them. I have used sella anat√≥mica saddles, and liked them. My Brooks actually all three have never let me down. Leather suspended saddles (let‚Äôs no it forget berthoud) are a deal if you plan on riding regularly. The saddle is the first upgrade you should get well in advance of a tour. Key point: think about a rear fender and definitely get a quality saddle Cover.
data.author: Bryan Fennelly

data.text: Brooks Cambium no break in period.
data.author: Paul R Manangan

data.text: Go to a bike store that offers fitting services and have them measure you for a saddle (or a full fit) and get recommendations from them based on that fit. Check that they have a friendly return policy that will allow you to try out for a couple of weeks. Put in some distance during the return period. Note any points of discomfort that persist and return to the store for updated recommendations if required.
data.author: Simon Tomkins

data.text: if the current saddle works for you, but needs updating/more prettiness, maybe try and find something that matches the size and shape. As you note, a saddle is a very personal choice. At most, I suggest looking to others for quality of brand rather than a specific saddle. Fwiw, I have used Fizik (probably too race-oriented), Selle Italia (many years, mostly commuting on a cx bike, wearing out quite a bit after 10 good years), WTB (stock saddle, never liked it), and Fabric (great value for the money, have done many longer road-bike rides with no issues).

data.text: You have so many recommendations already for saddles so perhaps a can add a vote to a professional Bike fitting at a bike shop. Moving your saddle a few millimeters forward or back, up or down, titling the saddle nose a tad or adjusting your handlebar height so you are not straining to reach make a massive difference to your sit comfort.

Good luck i have looked at Selle latest offerings, not for me i am afraid ..

data.author: Jo Lowe

data.text: How did you did on this? As an endurance/ultra rider I can tell you that this is very personal and what works for one person may or may not work for some one else., you only really fin out after 5 hour riding and never in the shop. The general rule is sit bones + 2 cm, but that does not count for how the nose fits between your thighs when peddling and the pressure points in that region. I have a female friend that has some very specific challenges thanks to a pelvis broken in a car crash. We are very excited about the developments in sadles from Ergon, and the work Endura has been doing with a famous bike filter on the padding in women cycling shorts. Endura offer their shorts (and longs) with different pad sizes depending on your saddle size ! Finally we are getting a parts of that compliment each other. ( Please note. I am not sponsored in any way by either brand) J
data.author: Julian Young

data.text: Brooks Cambium line is rubber rather than leather so no breaking in and it won't change either... that being said I bought My Brooks team pro in the mid 70s ... rode day rides for 10 years on it before heading off on long tours.. went thru cub & boy scouts in the late 50s camping, backpack back country hiking, with Korean War surplus gear.. Point: mostly moot, since my hips are not yours, thus neither is my opinion.. üçø
data.author: Robert Clark
